{\footnotesize\ttfamily void convert\+Protection\+Level (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{build_2doxygen_2src_2types_8h_abe8ad5992f8938a28f918f51b199aa19}{Member\+List\+Type}}}]{in\+List\+Type,  }\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{build_2doxygen_2src_2types_8h_a90e352184df58cd09455fe9996cd4ded}{Protection}}}]{in\+Prot,  }\item[{int $\ast$}]{out\+List\+Type1,  }\item[{int $\ast$}]{out\+List\+Type2 }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}

Computes for a given list type {\itshape in\+List\+Type}, which are the the corresponding list type(s) in the base class that are to be added to this list.

So for public inheritance, the mapping is 1-\/1, so out\+List\+Type1=in\+List\+Type Private members are to be hidden completely.

For protected inheritance, both protected and public members of the base class should be joined in the protected member section.

For private inheritance, both protected and public members of the base class should be joined in the private member section.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily static int find\+End\+Of\+Command (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const char $\ast$}]{s }\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [static]}}

For a string {\itshape s} that starts with a command name, returns the character offset within that string representing the first character after the command. For an alias with argument, this is the offset to the character just after the argument list.

Examples\+:

\item s==\char`\"{}a b\char`\"{} returns 1
\item s==\char`\"{}a\{2,3\} b\char`\"{} returns 6 = s==\char`\"{}\#\char`\"{} returns 0 
\end{DoxyItemize}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily bool get\+Defs\+Old (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_q_c_string}{QCString}} \&}]{sc\+Name,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_q_c_string}{QCString}} \&}]{mb\+Name,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_q_c_string}{QCString}} \&}]{args,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_member_def}{Member\+Def}} $\ast$\&}]{md,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_class_def}{Class\+Def}} $\ast$\&}]{cd,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_file_def}{File\+Def}} $\ast$\&}]{fd,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_namespace_def}{Namespace\+Def}} $\ast$\&}]{nd,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_group_def}{Group\+Def}} $\ast$\&}]{gd,  }\item[{bool}]{force\+Empty\+Scope,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{class_file_def}{File\+Def}} $\ast$}]{current\+File,  }\item[{bool}]{check\+CV }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}

Searches for a member definition given its name \textquotesingle{}member\+Name\textquotesingle{} as a string. member\+Name may also include a (partial) scope to indicate the scope in which the member is located.

The parameter \textquotesingle{}sc\+Name\textquotesingle{} is a string representing the name of the scope in which the link was found.

In case of a function args contains a string representation of the argument list. Passing 0 means the member has no arguments. Passing \char`\"{}()\char`\"{} means any argument list will do, but \char`\"{}()\char`\"{} is preferred.

The function returns TRUE if the member is known and documented or FALSE if it is not. If TRUE is returned parameter \textquotesingle{}md\textquotesingle{} contains a pointer to the member definition. Furthermore exactly one of the parameter \textquotesingle{}cd\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}nd\textquotesingle{}, or \textquotesingle{}fd\textquotesingle{} will be non-\/zero\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item if \textquotesingle{}cd\textquotesingle{} is non zero, the member was found in a class pointed to by cd.
\item if \textquotesingle{}nd\textquotesingle{} is non zero, the member was found in a namespace pointed to by nd.
\item if \textquotesingle{}fd\textquotesingle{} is non zero, the member was found in the global namespace of file fd. 
\end{DoxyItemize}

Searches for a scope definition given its name as a string via parameter {\ttfamily scope}.

The parameter {\ttfamily doc\+Scope} is a string representing the name of the scope in which the {\ttfamily scope} string was found.

The function returns TRUE if the scope is known and documented or FALSE if it is not. If TRUE is returned exactly one of the parameter {\ttfamily cd}, {\ttfamily nd} will be non-\/zero\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item if {\ttfamily cd} is non zero, the scope was a class pointed to by cd.
\item if {\ttfamily nd} is non zero, the scope was a namespace pointed to by nd. 
\end{DoxyItemize}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily void strip\+Irrelevant\+Const\+Volatile (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{class_q_c_string}{QCString}} \&}]{s }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}

According to the C++ spec and Ivan Vecerina\+:

Parameter declarations that differ only in the presence or absence of const and/or volatile are equivalent.

So the following example, show what is stripped by this routine for const. The same is done for volatile.

For Java code we also strip the \char`\"{}final\char`\"{} keyword, see bug 765070.


\begin{DoxyCode}{0}

\DoxyCodeLine{T* \textcolor{keyword}{const} param    -\/>   T* param         \textcolor{comment}{// not relevant}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const} T* param    -\/>   \textcolor{keyword}{const} T* param   \textcolor{comment}{// const needed}}

\end{DoxyCode}
